III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section Sufficiency of staff.
Description (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
1

perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A youth reported that they went AWOL 5/19/25. The youth stole a
knife while AWOL and brought it back to the facility and presented
it to staff. This was not the first time that the youth eloped from the
campus and brought a weapon back. This youth and other youth
often go AWOL.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed by phone on 5/22/2025.
Complainant did not provide any additional information.
Attempts were made to interview Youth A on 5/23/2025,
6/11/2025, and 6/13/2025. Youth A refused verbally to participate
in the interview.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 6/11/2025.
Staff 1 reported Youth A has been at the facility for a long time
and the AWOL behavior is a more recent development for him.
Staff 1 reported he has had conversations with Youth A about
safety and attempted to find out why this sudden behavioral
change in him. Staff 1 reported when Youth A begins to leave
campus he and other staff will follow him and attempt verbal
redirection until they cannot follow him anymore. For example if he
gets onto a bus or they lose line of sight. Staff 1 reported staff will
also follow in cars for as long as they can. Staff 1 reported at 15
minutes they make a police report. Staff 1 reported Youth A has
told him he likes to go and find vapes. Staff 1 reported he heard
that on one occasion Youth A brought back a knife and that it was
taken from him immediately. Staff 1 reported Youth A has brought
back vapes and a lighter while he has been working and that he
had to give them to staff prior to entering back into the facility.
Staff 1 reported the staff following will report to the supervisor who
reports to clinical who notifies the youth’s guardians and workers.
Staff 1 reported some confusion on how long to follow a youth
when they go AWOL, stating that it is not in the procedure.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 6/11/2025.
Staff 2 reported when Youth A has attempted to leave campus
they alert on call and follow him until he leaves campus and at that
time they continue to follow in vans. Staff 2 reported they attempt
verbal redirection and talk about safety to try to get Youth A to
come back to campus. Staff 2 denied being present for an AWOL
2

in which Youth A brought weapons or vapes back to campus
however did hear Youth A brought a knife back and police were
called to assist. Staff 2 reported he heard it was taken from him as
soon as possible. Staff 2 reported it is suspected Youth A’s
increased AWOLing is influenced by other youth, specifically
Youth B who he often goes with. Staff 2 reported they follow any
youth when they leave campus until they lose line of sight and
make a police report. Staff 2 reported once they return from
making the police report they alert on call and on call alerts the
youth’s worker. Staff 2 reported when a youth returns from AWOL
they are checked for items they should not have and a wand is
used to ensure they do not have any weapons on their person.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 6/11/2025.
Staff 3 reported when Youth A goes AWOL she and other staff will
follow him out while another staff will get the van to follow as well.
Staff 3 reported she has followed youth leaving campus while she
has line of sight. Staff 3 reported she and other staff will attempt to
verbally address with the youth attempting to leave what is going
on and encourage them to come back with them. Staff 3 reported
a police report is made and on call notified when they begin to
follow them. Staff 3 reported an incident report is made anytime a
youth leaves their cottage without permission whether they leave
campus or not. Staff 3 denied recalling Youth A returning from
AWOL with any weapons or vapes.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 6/11/2025.
Youth B reported he has gone AWOL with Youth A before. Youth
B reported he is trying not to go AWOL anymore to not get into
trouble. Youth B reported he and Youth A would try to buy stuff
from the store. Youth B reported one time he and Youth A brought
a knife back and police were at the facility and took it from them.
Youth B reported when they go AWOL the staff at the facility will
follow them on foot and in the van, asking them to come back with
them. Youth B was not sure how long or far staff follow them for.
Youth B reported they will tell them they want to make sure they
are okay and that they do not do anything else to get them to
come back. Youth B reported when he has come back from
AWOL he is checked with a metal detector to make sure he does
not have anything he should not have and asked if he is okay.
Documents Reviewed:
• Incident Report (IR) dated 3/19/25 authored by Staff 3
documents Youth A leaving without permission with staff
following until line of sight was lost. IR documents that
police were contacted.
• Incident Report dated 4/14/25 authored by Staff 4
documents Youth A leaving without permission with staff
3

following until line of sight was lost. IR documents that
police were contacted.
• Incident Report dated 4/14/25 authored by Staff 2
documents Youth A declining to watch a movie with the
other youth and walking to the woods. IR documents that
Youth A was followed until line of sight was lost and that a
police report was made.
• Incident Report dated 5/16/25 authored by Staff 1
documents Youth A declining to participate in a group
activity and leaving campus. IR documents Youth A was
followed until line of sight was lost and on call was
contacted.
• MCHS Residential Treatment AWOL Policy states that
youths attempting to AWOL are to be followed until line of
sight is lost, the shift supervisor should be contacted
immediately, a police report is to be made if line of sight is
lost, it is recommended to follow an AWOL youth in a
facility van, it is stated staff should not chase, utilize
physical management, and to remain calm while in pursuit
of an AWOL youth. Policy documents the therapist reports
the incident to parents/guardian/referring agencies.
• Email authored by Case Management Supervisor confirms
receipt of notifications of Youth A’s AWOL incidences on
3/19/25, 4/17/25, 5/14/25, and 5/16/25.
• CWLM documents contacts authored by Consultant
confirming notification receipt for Youth A’s AWOLs on
3/19/25, 4/17/25, 5/14/25, and 5/16/25.
Analysis There are no rule violations regarding this allegation. It was
consistently reported via staff and youth interviews staff followed
the facility’s AWOL Policy through appropriate attempts at
intervention, following youth while line of sight was present, and
made appropriate reports as confirmed via contact with DCWL
Consultant and Case Management Supervisor. It was consistently
reported Youth A was checked by staff upon return from his
AWOLs and all vapes, lighters as well as the knife brought back
was safely obtained upon his return.
Technical Assistance:
The facility should ensure all staff have full understanding of the
MCHS Residential Treatment AWOL Policy as it relates to length
of time to follow youth off campus. Staff 1 expressed uncertainty
regarding this policy.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
